content: Is there any particular reason why we can't give the grind attribute to Surjective and Injective, given we do give it to, say, LeftInverse and RightInverse?
grind has special support for Injective lemmas so tagging it probably isn't a good idea. Maybe Surjective would be worth tagging grind though?
Or maybe tagging Injective grind would not actually pose any problems? not sure
I just find sometimes I want to prove things about both and I end up needing to get to the meaning underneath.
And locally putting it in works, but is often kinda ugly, and it feels weird.

In certain cases I think it could make grind more inefficient to add this tag, for instance it will create existential hypotheses which grind will do cases on (and therefore increasing the number of split), and may end up avoiding higher-level reasoning steps using Surjective instead. So my instinct is to keep adding it locally, or having a local attribute in your file. In contrast, LeftInverse and RightInverse are just equalities, and having more of those in the context doesn't really make things much worse.
In case it's helpful to have the context, by the way, it was in this: #lean4 > `Surjective` iff `Injective` for `Fin n`
